elements.name: question8
elements.html:
A Critical Appraisal Task (CAT) is a training tool designed to enable trainees to address a clinical question using the best available evidence. Trainees are expected to appraise the relevant literature and, based upon this, to concisely provide a rationale for their chosen management. These tasks equip the trainee to continually adjust management approaches during their career as a paediatric surgeon, as new information becomes available. CATs are designed to approximate the framework expected during written components of the Fellowship Examination.

 

Learning outcomes

 

Critical appraisal is the process of carefully and systematically assessing the outcome of scientific research (evidence) to judge its reliability, value and relevance in a particular context. Critical appraisal is more than a review of the current literature and categorisation of level of evidence.

This Critical Appraisal Task (CAT) is intended to develop your skill as a healthcare professional to determine the extent to which the research evidence is applicable, unbiassed and relevant to your patients.

The learning outcomes of this CAT are to enable you to:

- organise the presentation to inform the reader of the key concepts in a logical and well-constructed format;

- demonstrate an ability to advance a logical argument using supporting scientific literature, including appropriately cited references;

- appraise and summarise the scientific literature to support your response to the questions;

- assess the relative value of different treatment options; and

- formulate evidence-based opinions in areas of importance or controversy in paediatric surgery.

 

The CAT question will be available from 11.59 PM (AEST) on Sunday 28th August 2022.

You are required to submit your response to the CAT in .pdf format by 11:59 PM (AEDT) on Sunday 20th November 2022.

You will receive feedback from your facilitators, and you may be asked to resubmit your initial response to the CAT.

CATs are open to all trainees. Trainees must submit and pass six CATs during training. It is mandatory for Mid- and Senior-SET trainees to submit a CAT unless they have fulfilled the requirement. If you choose to submit before Mid-SET, you will be marked at Mid-SET level.


In regards to the format, we suggest:

- using grades of recommendation 

- when quoting levels of evidence, please let us know at the beginning of the submission what standard you are using i.e. Oxford, NHRMC, so it can be marked accordingly 

- dot points rather than full essay style 

- word limit is a guide

-- please include the number of words used

-- not acceptable if >10% over the word limit

-- you can have a satisfactory answer using less than the word limit 

- tables summarising the levels of evidence for each study at the end of the submission are not necessary; we would prefer that the important studies are analysed in your paper itself 

- include what you will do for the patient at hand and ensure that you have justified it using the literature

elements.name: question4
elements.html:
Empyema

A four year old boy presents to the hospital with six days of cough and fevers despite oral antibiotics. On examination he is febrile to 38 degrees Celsius, tachycardic and mildly tachypnoeic, He is on 1L/min oxygen via nasal prongs and sitting up in bed. There is reduced air entry on the right side. Chest x-ray demonstrates a right pleural effusion. You are consulted after an ultrasound confirms the effusion. A COVID swab was negative.

Using the available evidence:

  • Outline your indications for intervention

  • Justify your surgical management

(1500 words)

rows.text: Clarity of presentation/setting out (e.g. introduction, discussion, conclusions, recommendations)
Review of literature (breadth, depth and relevance)
Evaluation of hypothesis, critique and context
Consideration of the relative value of different treatment options
Focus and relevance to the case or question
Demonstrates application of knowledge to clinical situation

Row 1.Column 1:
• Organisation difficult to follow
• Limited, disorganised or illogical presentation of key concepts
• Many spelling errors
• Many and/or major referencing errors
Row 1.Column 2:
• Generally well organised so that the reader can follow
• Key concepts adequately developed and presented
• Few spelling errors
• Referencing with minor errors
Row 1.Column 3:
• Well organised and sequenced
• Clear, logical presentation of key concepts
• Accurate spelling
• Accurately referenced

Row 2.Column 1:
• Few or no key references identified across breadth of topic
• Evidence presented from references is superficial or cursory in key areas.
• Presents irrelevant references
Row 2.Column 2:
• Adequate range of relevant references identified and presented across breadth of topic
• Evidence presented from references covers most of the key areas
• Presents relevant references
Row 2.Column 3:
• Comprehensive range of relevant references identified and presented across breadth of topic
• Evidence presented from references covers depth required in all key areas.
• Includes prime relevant references

Row 3.Column 1:
• Superficial or irrelevant critical analysis of the selected literature
• Minimal or misguided identification and analysis of areas of uncertainty
Row 3.Column 2:
• Critical analysis demonstrates reasonable interpretation of selected literature.
• Evaluates and critiques the evidence in key areas of uncertainty
Row 3.Column 3:
• Critical analysis demonstrates sophisticated, accurate interpretation of the selected literature.
• Evaluates and critiques most areas of uncertainty

Row 4.Column 1:
• Selected treatment is unlikely to be successful
• Rationale and justification of selected treatment are inadequate or flawed
• Minimal evaluation of limitations or risks of treatment options
Row 4.Column 2:
• Selected treatment is likely to be successful
• Rationale and justification for selected treatment are logical and defensible
• Adequate evaluation of limitations or risks of treatment options
Row 4.Column 3:
• Selected treatment is likely to be successful, accounting for variability
• Rationale and justification for selected treatment are logical and defensible, accounting for variability
• In-depth evaluation of limitations or risks of treatment options

Row 5.Column 1:
• Minimal coverage of important issues
• Contentious and/or current issues not addressed
Row 5.Column 2:
• Adequate coverage of important issues
• Acknowledges contentious and/or current issues
Row 5.Column 3:
• Comprehensive coverage of important issues
• Investigates and addresses contentious and/or current issues

Row 6.Column 1:
• Incorrect or minimal clinical interpretation of the case or situation
• Inaccurate or minimal clinical application of the case or situation
• One or more of the significant areas are misinterpreted or omitted
Row 6.Column 2:
• Adequate clinical interpretation appropriate to the case or situation
• Adequate clinical application appropriate to the case or situation
• Most of the significant areas are addressed
Row 6.Column 3:
• Accurate and comprehensive clinical interpretation appropriate to the case or situation
• Accurate and comprehensive clinical application appropriate to the case or situation
• All of the significant areas are addressed

elements.title: Assessment rubric mid-SET
elements.description: This assessment rubric provides scoring criteria and performance standards for activity categories.

elements.name: question7
elements.html:
Unsatisfactory - The work has seven or more ‘Below standard’ scores in any category
 
Borderline  - The work has three to six ‘Below standard’ scores in any category and/or has one or more ‘Below standard’ scores in the Critical analysis category
Re-submission is permitted
 
Satisfactory - The work has at least fourteen ’Meets standard’ scores, including all three in the Critical analysis category
